container-title: Va. Code Ann. §19.2-266. In Richmond Newspapers, Inc. v. Virginia, 448 U.S
note: Code Ann. §19.2–266 because the issue had not been sufficiently addressed on appeal. Id. at 562–63 n.4. See also Waller v. Georgia, 467 U.S. 39 (1984) (“the explicit Sixth Amendment right of the accused is no less protective of a public trial than the implicit First Amendment right of the press and public”); Press-Enterprise Co. v. Superior Court, 464 U.S. 501 (1984); Globe Newspaper Co. v. Superior Court, 457 U.S. 596 (1982) (court must articulate its findings for the record prior to closure).
title: The trial court may “exclude from the trial any persons whose presence would impair the conduct of a fair trial, provided that the right of the accused to a public trial shall not be violated
the Supreme Court found that the right of the public and press to attend criminal trials is guaranteed by the first and fourteenth amendments. The Court did not address the validity of Va
